title: TEMPERATURE REGULATION IN MICE OF THE GENUS SCOTINOMYS
abstract: Body temperature and metabolism were examined in Scotinomys teguina and S. xerampelinus during 2.5-hour exposures to ambient temperatures between 0 and 35°C. Thennal conductance at temperatures below thermoneutrality averaged 0.34 cc 02/gjhrjOC in the smaller species, teguina, and 0.28 cc O./g/ hrre in xerampelinus. The difference in mean conductance between species is st'ltistically significant. During cx-posurc to ambient temperatures near 35"C, deaths occurred in xerampelinus but not in tegttina. In the range 0 to 5°C, hypothermia was more common jn teguina than in xerampelinus. These differences in thennophysiology between the species are correlated with altitudinal distribution; xerampelinus is restricted to cool or cold highlands and teguina is found at lower, warmer altitudes. Although both are montane, tropical species, they adhere to broad patterns of thermoregulatory physiology established in studies of North American peromyscines of the genera PeramysclIs, Reithrodontomys, and Baiomys.

abstract.text: Body temperature and metabolism were examined in Scotinomys teguina and S. xerampelinus during 2.5-hour exposures to ambient temperatures between 0 and 35°C. Thennal conductance at temperatures below thermoneutrality averaged 0.34 cc 02/gjhrjOC in the smaller species, teguina, and 0.28 cc O./g/ hrre in xerampelinus. The difference in mean conductance between species is st'ltistically significant. During cx-posurc to ambient temperatures near 35"C, deaths occurred in xerampelinus but not in tegttina. In the range 0 to 5°C, hypothermia was more common jn teguina than in xerampelinus. These differences in thennophysiology between the species are correlated with altitudinal distribution; xerampelinus is restricted to cool or cold highlands and teguina is found at lower, warmer altitudes. Although both are montane, tropical species, they adhere to broad patterns of thermoregulatory physiology established in studies of North American peromyscines of the genera PeramysclIs, Reithrodontomys, and Baiomys.

body_text.text: The "brown mice" of the genus Scotinomys inhabit the mountains of Middle America from southern Mexico to Panama. Though they are related to species in South America, closest affinities may be with Middle or North American peromyscine genera (Hooper and Musser, 1964) . Among these latter taxa, thermoregulatory physiology has been investigated in Peromyscus (for example, McNab and Morrison, 1963) , Baiomys (Hudson, 1965) , and Reithrodontomys (Pearson, 1960) . Comparative information on thel'moregulation in Scotinomys may prove to be valuable in understanding adaptation of pcromyscine rodents to tropical environments.

The genus Scotinomys includes some 15 named taxa, but there are probably only two species, S. xerampelinus and S. teguina. These differ in size and other anatomical characters. Although both species are restricted to mountains, they have different altitudinal and geographic distributions. S. xerampelinus occurs at altitudes between 2100 and 3300 meters in Costa Rica and western Panama, whereas S. teguina occurs from southern Mexico to western Panama, principally at altitudes between 1000 and 2500 (but up to 2940) meters. In Costa Rica and Panama, the two species occupy predominantly different altitudinal belts, with areas of contact or sympatry at the lower edge of the belt occupied by xerampelinus. Studies of thernl0regulatory physiology may be significant in deternlining what attributes of the two species are associated with their restriction to different altitudes.

Eighteen adults, nine of each species, were studied. Ten of these were captured in the ~vild in Ap~il or May ~969; eight were born in the laboratory to wild-caught parents. Exper-Imental ammaJs or theIr parents were taken as follows: S. teguill(l-COSTA RICA: Puntarenas, Monte Verde (1430 m), five males and one female, and Hacienda Tapanti (1200 m), two males. NICARAGUA: Matagalpa, Santa Maria de Ostuma (1300 m), one male. s.
xerampelintlS-COSTA RICA: Cartago, Vold.n Turrialba (2600 m), one male, two females, and Volcan Irazu (2550-3000 m), five males, one female.

The animals were housed, one or two to a cage, at a temperature of about 23"C and a relative humidity of about 60 per cent. They were fed rat chow, oabneal, sunflower seeds, and mealwonns (Tenebrio). Food and water were provided ad libitum except during and immediately before experimentation. The mice received a daily regime of about 12 hours light and 12 hours darkness. All experiments were performed in the afternoon, when the Scotinomys in the laboratory colony typically were resting.

Prior to experimentation, an animal was denied food and water for about 5 hours. It was then weighed and sealed into a metal metabolism chamber, which had been fashioned from a new, quart paint can. The chamber had inlet and outlet ports for air on the lid, and the mouse rested on a screen floor that was raised above the bottom of the chamber. Air temperature inside the metabolism chamber was maintained to within ± IOC of a desired level by placing the chamber in a temperature regulating cabinet. Dry air was passed through the chamber at a rate of 450 to 480 cubic centimeters per minute during exposure to temperatures between 0 and 30°C. At 35°C, the rate of flow was about 630 cc/min. Exposure to a single selected temperature lasted for 2.5 hours except in a few instances noted in the results. Oxygen conswnption was measured continuously using a Beckman G-2 paramagnetic oxygen analyzer in conjunction with the open flow system outlined above. Temperature inside the metabolism chamber was monitored by a copper-constantan thermocouple connected to a Honeywell Class 15 recording potentiometer. At the end of the 2.5-hour experimental period, the animal was removed from the metabolism chamber, and its body temperature measured using a flexible thermocouple probe connected to the recording potentiometer. The probe was constructed of 40-gauge copper and constantan wires welded at the tip and threaded into Intramedic PESO polyethylene tubing (0.97 millimeters in outside diameter). The probe was inserted 2 to 3 centimeters into the rectum. Body temperature was generally measured within 30 seconds of removal of the animal from the chamber. The mouse was weighed again, and the terminal weight is the one reported in the results. Then the animal was returned to its cage and given food and water. It was not studied again until at least the next day. Unless noted otherwise in the results, metabolic rate showed no obvious upward or downward trend during the final hour of the experiment, and the reported rate represents average oxygen consumption over a 20-to 30-minute interval of the last hour during which metabolism was relatively low and constant. Metabolic rate is expressed as volume of dry oxygen, corrected to STP, consumed per hour per gram of terminal animal weight.

The individuals of S. xerampelinus that were studied averaged 3.2 grams heavier than those of S. teguina (Table 1) . This difference in mean weight is significant according to the two-tailed i-test (P < 0.02). Data from our laboratory colony and from field-caught specimens confirm the larger size of xerampelinus.

Body temperatures varied considerably in both species and, at ambient temperatures of 15 to 30°C, tended to be higher in ieguina than in xemmpelinus (Table 1) . Rectal temperatures of teguina ranged from 35.5 to 39.5°C and averaged 37.6 at ambient temperatures of 15 to 30°C. For xerampelinus, the range was 34.1 to 38.5°C, and the mean was 36.2. The interspecific difference ~ate gIven m F,g. 1 was taken before the declme, thus did not exist concurrently with body temperature given here.
"**. Rate of oxyge~ consumption fen rapidly from beginning of experiment and is not indicated in Fig. 1 Experiment was tenmnated after only 70 minutes. .
in mean rectal temperature at 15 to 30°C is significant according to the twotailed Mann-Whitney U-test (P < 0.02).

All animals of both species that had rectal temperatures below 32°C exhibited steadily declining rates of oxygen consumption at the end of their experimental runs. This was true for animal number 37 when tested at an ambient tempera-. . '" ture of about SoC, although in this case the decline was slow enough such as not to warrant special note in Table 1 . Some animals with rectal temperatures below 32°C, including one with a temperature of 31.9°C, also disl?la ye d clearly perceptible behavioral lethargy when removed from the metaboh~m cha~ber.

On the basis of these observations, it seems appropriate to conslder anImals with such rectal temperatures to have been hypothclmic. Of the eight teguina tested at 0 or SoC (or both), three exhibited hypothermia (all at SOC), and one died (after 70 minutes at SOC). Of the seven xerampelinus examined at these ambient temperatures , none became hypothennic at 5°C and only OIle did so at O°C. The teguina thus were less able to thernlOregula te at low temperatures than wcre the xerampelinus .
Three xerampelinus were studied at ambient temperatures of about 35°c'

Two died (number 26 after 65 minutes and number 210 after 45 minutes), and the third had a rectal temperature that waS substantially highclthan its temperature after tests at lower ambient temperatures . Of the three teguina studied at ambient temperatures near 35°C, one (number 56) displayed a substantially elevated rectal temperature, and the others had temperatures only slightly higher than those exhibited during tests at 30°C. These results suggest that teguina may be able to accommodate to high temperatures better than xerampelinus, although a firm conclusion cannot be drawn owing to the small number of animals studied. There was no evidence of salivation in either species. Knowledge of humidity is important in appraising responses to high temperatures because ambient water vapor pressure influences the effectiveness of mechanisms for evaporative cooling. Relative humidity in the metabolism chamber during experiments at 35°C cannot be calculated with precision because water loss from animals was not measured. If it is assumed, however, that loss of body weight during an experiment represented only loss of water, the method of Lasiewski et al. (1966) permits calculation of an average relative humidity. This ranged between 10 and 40 per cent for the six experiments performed at 35°C. These values are likely well in excess of the aemal values for average relative humidity inasmuch as total weight loss reflected loss of dry fecal matter as well as loss of water. On the other hand, relative humidity may have exceeded the calculated values at times if the generation of water vapor varied from time to time (as is expected, since at least urinary and fecal losses would likely be intermittent).

Metabolic rates are depicted in Figs. 1 and 2 for all experiments except the three in which animals died and three others cited in footnotes to Table 1 . In both species, there was substantial variation among individuals in the quantitative relationship between oxygen consumption and ambient temperature. vVe have thus chosen to identify the data for each individual in the figures. A linear least-squares regression of oxygen consumption on ambient temperature Most of the regression lines intersect the temperature axis at temperatures that are 2 to 6°e higher than the body temperatures of the animals, and the regressions do not take account of variation in body temperature with ambient temperature. Thus, the slopes of the regressions do not provide an accurate measure of thermal conductance at temperatures below thermoneutrality. Conmetabolic rate ductancc was detennined as the ratio -;-c'"7-:----c-----;-:----,----body temperature-ambient temperature for all experiments at ambient temperatures between 0 and 25°C. Such temperatures were clearly below the zone of thermoneutraIity, and conductance did not vary systematically with temperature in this range. Experiments in which metabolic rate was not stable were excluded. The thermal conductance of each individual Scotinomys was estimated by averaging the conductances for all experiments on the individual (Table 2) . One-way analyses of variance indi-cated that there were significant differences in conductance among individuals within each species (P < 0.025 for teguina, P < 0.005 for xerampelinus). Estimated conductances for the individuals of each species were averaged to obtain mean conductances of 0.34 cc 02/g/hrjOC for teguina and 0.28 cc Oz/g/hrrC for xerampelinus (Table 2) . A two-tailed t-test utilizing the individual conductances in Table 2 indicated that the mean conductances of the two species are significantly different (0.02 < P < 0.05).

Some of the variation in metabolic response among individuals of a species was likely a reflection of different activity levels. Observations of mice both in the animal colony and during experiments indicated that some were more active than others. The fact that, for some animals, rate of oxygen consumption varied erratically from one ambient temperature to another also suggests that activity had an influence on some observed rates. We feel it appropriate to view those individuals that exhibited relatively low metabolic rates as repre• sentative of the resting condition for their species.

All xerampelinus exhibited relatively similar metabolic rates at test temperarures around 30°C, Rates ranged from 1.7 to 2.5 cc Oz/g/hr, with a mean of 2.1 and a standard deviation of 0.24 cc 02/g/hr. These rates likely provide a reasonably close estimate of resting metabolism at approximately thermally neutral temperatures. Rates for teguina at around 30°C were much more variable and did not permit a confident estimate of resting metabolism near thermo• neutrality. The three lower rates, but not the remaining six, for teguina were within the range established in xerampelinus (Fig. 1 ),

Observation in the laboratory and field indicates that teguina is the more active, eXCitable, and aggressive; it vigorously resists handling, whereas xerampelinus responds rather placidly to such treatment. S. teguina is slightly smaller than its congenor and occurs at lower elevations, where macrocIimatic temperarures are higher. Each of these three interspecific distinctions-excitability, body size, and ecological distribution-bear on the interpretation of the physiological infonnation presented here.
body_text.section: Comparison of S. teguina and S. xerampelinus

body_text.text: The data of McNab and Morrison (1963) on body temperature and activity in Peromyscus suggest that the higher temperatures of teguina (compared to xerampelinus) at ambient temperarures of 15 to 300C may have been due at least in part to their greater excitability. The higher variance in metabolic rate among individuals of teguina at ambient temperatures of 25 and 30°C also may be attributable to the excitability of this species.
body_text.section: Comparison of S. teguina and S. xerampelinus

body_text.text: McNab and Morrison (1963) , Hayward (1965) , and Hart (1953) found inverse relationships between thermal conductance and body size in mice of the genus Peromyscus. In this context, it is not surprising that teguina exhibited a higher conductance than xerampelinus. McNab and Morrison present evi- 8-12.8 ( 12.11 21.8-23.1 (20.3) Villa Mills 3096 2.0-5.7 ( 4.2) 14. 5-16.9 (15.7) dence that the conelation between weight and conductance is based not only on the higher surface-to-mass ratio of smaller animals, but also on differences in pelage or other factors. The data on Scotinomys are insufficient for an analysis of this type.
body_text.section: Comparison of S. teguina and S. xerampelinus

body_text.text: Temperatures for three localities in Costa Rica illustrate the contrasting climatic regimes of the species (Table 3) . At the elevations inhabited by teguina, macrocIimatic temperatures are moderate throughout the year. Average monthly maximum and average monthly minimum may be estimated as about 22°C and 12°C, respectively, for much of the range of the species. At the higher altitudes where xerampelinus Jives, macroclimatic temperatures are typically much lower. Temperatures of 5 to 10°C are commonplace, and freezing conditions may be expected. At Villa Mills in 1967, the average monthly mean temperature never exceeded IO.BoC, and the average monthly minimum was 5.7°C or less (as low as 2.0°C in March).
body_text.section: Comparison of S. teguina and S. xerampelinus

body_text.text: The extent of differences between rnicroclimates of the two species in their respective altitudinal zones is unknown. Most of the time, individuals of both species probably are in cavities below ground or in runways through vegetation, and thus may encounter their macroenvironment only for brief periods.
body_text.section: Comparison of S. teguina and S. xerampelinus

body_text.text: Our data indicate that teguina experiences more thennOl'egulatory difficulty than xerampelinus at ambient temperatures of 0 to 5°C. This is of particular interest because macroclimatie temperatures commonly enter this range in the habitats of xerampelinus, but not in those of teguina. Acknowledging our ignorance of microclimatic conditions, the possibility exists that environmental temperatures may play a role in restricting the geographically Widespread, seemingly more aggressive, teguina from geographically displacing xeram-pelinu8. Our results also suggest that teguina may be better able than its congenor to accommodate to temperatures around 35°C. Macroclimatic temperatures probably seldomly enter this range in the habitats of either species (Table  3) . MicrocIimatic temperatures would be expected to do so more frequently at the lower altitudes occupied by teguina. In evaluating these conelations between thennophysiology and altitudinal distribution, the present study can only be viewed as preliminary.
body_text.section: Comparison of S. teguina and S. xerampelinus

body_text.text: The species of Scotinomys exhibit thennophysiological differences from other, related North American taxa that have been studied, hut the differences appear to be no greater than those seen among the other taxa themselves.
body_text.section: Comparison of Scotinomys and its North American Relatives

body_text.text: Variability of body temperature comparable to that seen in Scotinomys at moderate ambient temperatures appears to be essentially universal among peromyscine mice (Hudson, 1965; MacMillen, 1965; McNab and Morrison, 1963; MUlie, 1961; Smith and Criss, 1967) . Elevation of body temperature at ambient temperatures of 3SoC and above is commonly seen among peromyscines (for example, McNab and Morrison, 1963) , hut death at as Iowa temperature as 35°C appears to be unCOmmon. Reithrodontomys megalotis and some species or subspecies of Peromyscus usually do not exhibit hypothennia at 0 to SoC when well fed (Hayward, 1965; MacMillen, 1965; McNab and Morrison, 1963; Pearson, 1960) . Other Peromyscus, especially some desert taxa, have a tend• eoey toward hypothermia that equals or exceeds that seen in S. teguina (McNab and Morrison, 1963) . The possibility of torpor has not been investigated in Scotinomys, but it desenres attention in view of the hypothermia evidenced by individuals 6f both species at low temperatures and the recent demonstration of torpor in other peromyscines (Hudson, 1965; Morhardt and Hudson, 1966) .
body_text.section: Comparison of Scotinomys and its North American Relatives

body_text.text: The S. teguina and S. xerampelinus used in this study had mean body weights of about 12 and IS grams, respectively. Kleiber's (1961) equation relating basal metabolism to weight thus predicts basal metabolic rates of about 1.8 cc Oz/g/hr for teguioo and 1.7 cc 02/g/hr for xerampelinus. Our estimate of mean resting metabolism for xerampelinus at ambient temperatures around 30°C is just 0.4 cc Odg/hr higher than the predicted basal metabolic rate for the species. The metabolic rates of certain teguina at 300C showed a similar approximation to the predicted basal level. It thus appears likely that basal metabolic rates in Scotinomys will prove to be rather typical for mammals of their size.
body_text.section: Comparison of Scotinomys and its North American Relatives

body_text.text: Various authors, studying a number of species of Peromyscus, have reported thermal conductances of 0.16--0.25 cc 02/g/hr/oC in animals averaging IS.9-21.5 grams in body weight (Hart, 1953; Hayward, 1965; MacMiIlen, 1965; McNab and Morrison, 1963; Morrison and Ryser, 1951) . Pearson (1960) reported a conductance of 0.27 cc 02/g/hr;oC in Reithrodontomys megalotis weighing 9 grams, and calculation from his data suggests a value of 0.24-0.2S cc 02/g/hr/oC for 12-gram animals. Hudson (196S) obtained conductances of 0.40-0,48 cc 02/g/hr;oC in Baiomys taylori weighing 6.5--8.0 grams. The values obtained for Scotinomys are thus within the range of expectation that might be sunnised from body weight and data on other peromyscines.
body_text.section: Comparison of Scotinomys and its North American Relatives
